name: MC 10
keyboard: QWERTY / AZERTY, Calculator style keyboard, 48 keys, Basic statements written above keysSHIFT, CONTROL, ENTER, BREAK
ram: 4 kb (up to 20 kb), 3142 bytes left for user
graphics: With Basic : 64 x 32, 8 colorsWith machine-code : up to 128 x 192, 2 colorsWith machine-code and 16k expansion RAM : 256 x 192, 2 colors
sound: Beeper with variable pitch and duration
ports: RGB DIN8 or RF jack (USA) video out, Expansion port, Tape (DIN6), Serial (DIN5), power IN
power: 8.0v AC 1.5A (MATRA Alice PSU can be used)
description:
The Tandy MC 10 (MC means Micro Color) was designed as an "initiation" computer to compete with the Timex Sinclair 1000, the american version of the Sinclair ZX-81. It was more expensive than the Sinclair machine, but outpassed it in every category. It had sound, color, more memory and even a better keyboard.

In fact, the MC-10 is basically a cut down version of the Tandy "Coco" computers, but didn't have as much success as its big brothers.

It is fully compatible with the first version of the Matra Alice  (a French computer). Actually both are the same computer (except for the case color, the Alice is red and the Tandy is white).
_______________________

shot.description: <br><font color="red"><strong>> TOP VIEW</strong></font><br><blockquote>I have a little game for you : <br><br> Search for the "V" key... <br><br> Yes, this must be a fabrication default...</blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> REAR VIEW</strong></font><br><blockquote>From left to right : <br><br> - power IN<br> - RGB video out (DIN8)<br> - Expansion slot (cached)<br> - Reset button (soft reset)<br> - Serial socket (DIN5)<br> - Tape-recorder (DIN6)</blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> EUROPEAN BOX (?)</strong></font><br><blockquote>Maybe this box was blue (instead of red for the US version) in order to differenciate the MC-10 from the Alice which all visual communication was based on the red color...</blockquote>

advert.description: <br><font color="red"><strong>> UK ADVERT SEPT. 1983</strong></font><br><blockquote></blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> US ADVERT NOV. 1987</strong></font><br><blockquote>Advert said:<br><font color="#666666"> Compaq has long been recognized as the world leader in both 80386 technology and portable computing. Si it's not surprising that we would combine the two.<br> But no one expected the new Compaq Portable 386 to run at 20 MHz. And no one even dreamed that it would offer 100 MB of storage, disk caching, and much, much more...</font></blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> FRENCH AD (JAN. 1985)</strong></font><br><blockquote>"I met Apple IIc" <br><br> French advert from MAJUSCULE distributor.</blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> FRENCH ADVERT (NOV. 1979)</strong></font><br><blockquote>This is the only SILEX advert known so far... <br><br> It says : "Silex, a stone in our competitors garden." <br><br> Silex means flint in french, a stone mainly used in prehistoric times as tools and weapons. </blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> JAPANESE ADVERT (1985)</strong></font><br><blockquote><p class="petitgris">Thanks to <a href="http://www.pugly.juice.or.jp/pugly/oldpc/" target="_blank">Pugly's web site</a> for this picture.</p></blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> U.S. ADVERT (1983) </strong></font><br><blockquote>Advert says:<br><br><font color="#666666"> What makes the QX-10 the most remarkably usable computer to date is a unique software system called VALDOC...<br><br> ... VALDOCS may be all the software you will never need. Right out of the box, it's a sophisticated <i>word processor</i>; an <i>information indexer</i> for easy acces to files; an <i>electronic mail system</i>;a <i>calculator</i>;an <i>apointment book</i> and <i>notepad</i>; and a <i>high resolution business graph drawing system</i>...</font></blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> FRENCH ADVERT (JULY 84)</strong></font><br><blockquote>''The Laser 200, a Secam color micro-computer really very suprising''</blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> ADVERT</strong></font><br><blockquote>First advert from 'Byte' magazine</blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> FRENCH ADVERT.</strong></font><br><blockquote>"For 1690 FF, wire all your family to the Laser 310"</blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> FRENCH ADVERT (JAN. 1985)</strong></font><br><blockquote>"It's him" <br><br> This is not an Apple official advert, but from french distributor called Micro Informatique Diffusion (MID)</blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> GERMAN LEAFLET #2</strong></font><br><blockquote>"This flexibly expandable computer grows by the increase of business activities and the rising requirements."<br><br> A reliable office computer, which can flexibly adapt to the business work, as it is essential for the office to execute resulting works promptly, correctly, and precisely.<br> A user-friendly conceived EDP-system like the MZ-3541 is essential, particularly for small to medium sized companies.<br> The MZ-3541 contributes for a substantial increase of the productivity in the office by the assumption of routine works. SHARP has designed the new MZ-3541 in such a way that it can be used for the most diverse resulting office works. And because multiple peripheral devices are available, the system can grow dynamically with the business activities.<br><br> The MZ-3541 is the result of Sharp's extensive market study and ergonomics studies. The free mobile keyboard makes data input and the operation easier and allows for spatial conditions an adapted installation of the system possible.<br> Sharp's MZ-3541 - the complete system for the business data processing.      <p class="petitgris">Courtesy of <b>www.sharpmz.org</b></p></blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> BROCHURE #3</strong></font><br><blockquote></blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> AMTEXT BROCHURE #1</strong></font><br><blockquote></blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> M-SERIES BROCHURE - PAGE 4</strong></font><br><blockquote><p class="petitgris">Thanks to Juraj Mucko for this picture</p></blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> UK ADVERT</strong></font><br><blockquote>November 1987<br><br> Special Spectrum offers before christmas period. Packages including a Sinclair joystick and 6 games.<br><br> Advert said:<br><font color="#666666"> The new Sinclair ZX Spectrum+3 is a real hero because it helps you to be one.<br> The fantastic 128K memory gives you the power to outsmart the most sophisticated ennemy...<br> ...But the real hero is the person who buy it...</font></blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> ADVERT</strong></font><br><blockquote><p class="petitgris">Picture courtesy of <a href="http://www.sbrowning.com/vintage">Steve Browning, www.sbrowning.com/vintage</a>.</p></blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> MAIL ORDER</strong></font><br><blockquote>Computer assisted mail-order <br><br> As soon as the home computers could communicate easily through modem with large computer sites, the major mail-order companies had the idea to sell products to the computers users. This  concept was facilitated in France by the free distribution of the 'Minitel' Videotex terminal that was gradually integrated into home computers. The success gained by this system in France did not have any equal in the rest of the world.  </blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> UK ADVERT, OCT. 1983</strong></font><br><blockquote>From Personal Computer World magazine.<br> Advert says:<br><font color="#666666"> This is an entirely new computer system. It was designed with both eyes fixed firmly on the future. So that whatever shape the future takes, we'll be able to fit it into the system. Just as simply as the peripherals and software already available fit into the system. That way, the system will grow with you. And you'll never get left behind. <br><br> Based around the Z80A microprocessor, and utilising Microsoft BASIC, Aquarius has 8K ROM and 4K RAM resident within its console. It is able to provide up to 16 colours and resolution of 320 x 192, and generates its sound directly through the television's speakers. <br><br> With twin cartridge ports, the mini-expander allows simultaneous use of additional RAM and software cartrldges. Twin disc game hand controls are included and the unit provides two additional sound channels. The 16K RAM cartridge plugs into either the console or the mini-expander, increasing Aquarius's RAM capacity to 20K. <br><br> With the ability to reproduce the entire graphic and character set of Aquarius at 80 characters a second, the printer's 40 column output allows transcription of the complete monitor image. <br><br> Using standard audio cassettes, the data recorder provides storage for programs and information, and allows the use of cassette based software. Incorporating a digital tape counter and transmission indicator, it operates sequential searching. <br><br> A large number of games, designed to take advantage of Aquarius's sophisticated colour and sound capabilities, are available on cartridges that plug into the console either direct, or through the mini-expander. Cassette based games can be used via the data recorder. <br><br> A wide range of preprogrammed cartridges is available, including the LOGO teaching program and practical home data systems like FILEFORM and the spreadsheet calculator package FINFORM. </font></blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> NEWBURRY BROCHURE #3</strong></font><br><blockquote><p class="petitgris">Courtesy of <b>www.oldcomputers.freeserve.co.uk </b></p></blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> US ADVERT (MAY 1983)</strong></font><br><blockquote>No info in this advert about the display that could be used (TV, composite, colour, B/W?)</blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> FRENCH ADVERT (1984)</strong></font><br><blockquote></blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> COMMODORE WATCHES!</strong></font><br><blockquote>While manufacturing and selling calculators in 1977, Commodore sold wristwatches.<p class="petitgris">Thanks to <b>Chuck Guzis</b></p></blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> MAGAZINE COVER</strong></font><br><blockquote>The TO-7/70 made the cover of french magazine Micro7 on february 1985.</blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> COMPARISON CHART #2</strong></font><br><blockquote><p class="petitgris">Thanks to Juraj Mucko for this picture</p></blockquote>

emulator.name: The MESS project
emulator.description: This multi-platform emulator can emulate the MC-10
